1. What is a Field?

A field is an algebraic structure with two operations, addition and multiplication, in which every non-zero element has a multiplicative inverse.

Field Axioms

A field $K, +, \cdot$ satisfies the following axioms:

  1. Addition: $K, +$ is an abelian group
    • Associativity: $(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)$
    • Commutativity: $a + b = b + a$
    • Identity Element: $a + 0 = a$
    • Inverse Element: $a + (-a) = 0$
  2. Multiplication: $K \setminus \{0\}, \cdot$ is an abelian group
    • Associativity: $(a \cdot b) \cdot c = a \cdot (b \cdot c)$
    • Commutativity: $a \cdot b = b \cdot a$
    • Identity Element: $a \cdot 1 = a$
    • Inverse Element: $a \cdot a^{-1} = 1$
  3. Distributive Law: $a \cdot (b + c) = a \cdot b + a \cdot c$

2. Examples of Fields

Standard Fields

Hierarchy of standard fields:

$$\mathbb{Q} \subset \mathbb{R} \subset \mathbb{C}$$

with the properties:

  • $\mathbb{Q}$: Field of rational numbers
  • $\mathbb{R}$: Field of real numbers
  • $\mathbb{C}$: Field of complex numbers

Finite Fields

Example: $\mathbb{F}_5 = \{0,1,2,3,4\}$

Addition table:

$$ \begin{array}{c|ccccc} + & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\ \hline 0 & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\ 1 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 0 \\ 2 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 0 & 1 \\ 3 & 3 & 4 & 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 4 & 4 & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \end{array} $$

Multiplication table:

$$ \begin{array}{c|ccccc} \cdot & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\ \hline 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\ 2 & 0 & 2 & 4 & 1 & 3 \\ 3 & 0 & 3 & 1 & 4 & 2 \\ 4 & 0 & 4 & 3 & 2 & 1 \end{array} $$

3. Characteristic of a Field

Definition

The characteristic $\text{char}(K)$ of a field $K$ is defined as:

$$\text{char}(K) = \min\{n \in \mathbb{N} \mid n \cdot 1_K = 0_K\}$$

If no such $n$ exists, we set $\text{char}(K) = 0$.

Properties

For a field $K$:

  • $\text{char}(K) = 0$ or $\text{char}(K) = p$ prime number
  • If $\text{char}(K) = p$, then: $\forall a,b \in K: (a + b)^p = a^p + b^p$

4. Field Extensions

Definition

A field extension $L/K$ consists of two fields with $K \subset L$.

The degree of extension is defined as:

$$[L:K] = \dim_K(L)$$

Example of a field extension chain:

$$\mathbb{Q} \subset \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2}) \subset \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3}) \subset \mathbb{C}$$

Types of Extensions

  • Algebraic: $\forall \alpha \in L, \exists p \in K[X]: p(\alpha) = 0$
  • Transcendental: $\exists \alpha \in L, \forall p \in K[X]: p(\alpha) \neq 0$
  • Normal: $\forall p \in K[X]: p$ irreducible $\Rightarrow p$ splits over $L$
  • Separable: $\forall \alpha \in L: \mu_\alpha$ has only simple roots

5. Constructions with Compass and Straightedge

Principle

A number $\alpha$ is constructible with compass and straightedge if and only if:

$$\exists K_0 = \mathbb{Q} \subset K_1 \subset \cdots \subset K_n \text{ with } [K_i : K_{i-1}] = 2 \text{ and } \alpha \in K_n$$

Classical Problems

  • Squaring the circle: $\pi$ is transcendental over $\mathbb{Q}$
  • Doubling the cube: $\sqrt[3]{2}$ is not constructible
  • Trisecting an angle: $\cos\frac{\pi}{9}$ is not constructible

6. Applications of Fields

Coding Theory

Reed-Solomon codes over $\mathbb{F}_{2^m}$:

$$C = \{(f(\alpha_1), \ldots, f(\alpha_n)) \mid f \in \mathbb{F}_{2^m}[X], \deg(f) < k\}$$

Cryptography

Elliptic curves over $\mathbb{F}_p$:

$$E: y^2 = x^3 + ax + b \pmod{p}$$

Galois Theory

Fundamental theorem of Galois theory:

$$\text{Gal}(L/K) \cong \text{Aut}(L/K)$$
